com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

last_replies.name: fixinga OP here
last_replies.com:
>>2517775
nice job anon, make sure u get the same type of cap and ratings...


>>2517799
for de-soldering, I would highly recommend using a solder sucker/pump like a goot GS-108 or TP-100 which will generally work much faster and stress the pads less from my experience especially for someone who never used solder wick b4.
also might want to watch these first before u start if u haven't soldered b4:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL926EC0F1F93C1837

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLBXXuFXCtmtqlamIEfu3lSTzM5t1k2cx_

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0wI-5YZQm4

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vpgMn88Qfjs

follow the steps and complete the primary check/repair, then you should go for a secondary diagnoses, which has 3 golden roles:

1. during this stage u will have to power up the board, the best way to power it is an isolation transformer, so the board is kept floating (galvanically isolated) this will reduce the risk of electrocution, also install a fast acting low current breaker or an incandescent lightbulb/heater or a fuse inline for added safety against short circuits accidental and otherwise, i personally use a 200w ceramic heater it if it glows i know there is a short and due to the PTC nature of the heater it limits the current enough to not cause catastrophic failure...
u could work on it on that state, but still i wouldn't recommend that for a beginner, so wear gloves and boots while working, and if u don't have access to an isolation transformer u have to use a GFCI/RDC outlet or breaker in line with circuit u are powering:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=olq9wdeNS4c

2.make sure yk where ur hands are!! keep ur hands off the board and the board always powered down at all times except during the test!!!


3. thou shalt check voltages, start from the primary side, since the voltages there are known for the most part, if they are in the ball park (+10v or -10v) its ok, any thing higher u should investigate the primary components

name: Doctor Eli Selig
sub: Glow in the dark Writing Computer
com:
Good Morning /diy/ers!

I have come from the Dra/g/on Maid Board to ask about glow-in-the-dark paint.

I have a Writing Computer.
>Writing Computer
https://www.clockworkpi.com/devterm

I like her a lot but she doesn't have a backlit keyboard. I would like to make the whole Writing Computer glow in the dark as brightly as possible so I can operate the keyboard in the dark.

Is there some kind of clear coating or paint which can be used to achieve this?

What is the best technique for bright glowing that lasts a long time?

Thank you /diy/ers for reading my post.
filename: Welcome to the Dra[g]on Maid board

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2519695
I don't believe you will get a satisfactory result by coating the entire device in luminescent material. The substance would be radiating light over top of the printed surfaces. This is a much different effect than shining a light on a reflective surface. It would be more akin to the glare of light on a monitor, where-in the monitor is trying to emit light, but the surface of the screen is reflecting light in front of the monitor's light. It would wash out the printed letters on the keyboard and make them unreadable.
Perhaps that is okay, if you are a touch-typist and not trying to read the keyboard. But if that were the case, why would you be asking for a lighting solution? The keyboard appears to already have the usual tactile markers for hand placement.
But I think you'd get a much better effect by just detail painting in the accents you need lighted, like the printed letters on each key.

Furthermore, luminescent materials are not "free energy." They do require something to power them.
Some do retain the charge imparted by exposure to UV light and release it gradually after being removed, but the effect of relying on the very limited energy capacity of the coating will likely be underwhelming.
There are radio-luminescent materials like tritium paint. You will pay accordingly for the quality, but these do last several years.
But, ultimately the most DIY feasible solution is just to apply phosphorescent paint that reacts to UV light, and then use a UV light to illuminate it. You will obviously need to power the UV light source, but this is not a difficult DIY problem to solve. You could just put a headlamp on for the purpose.

Actually, why NOT just wear a fucking headlamp, perhaps with a red filter to be less offensive in the dark? Better than fucking about with paint and shit.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Hello. Which OPamp would best be used with pic related equalizer? https://sound-au.com/articles/eq.ht<wbr>m

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2520895
Any op-amp designed for audio use, like an OPA2134. TL074s are pretty common too. I recommend EEVblog's video on jellybean op-amps. You may want to check the noise specs to ensure your signal is staying significantly above the noise floor for a given input amplitude. Also specs like common-mode input range, slew-rate, etc. could be handy to check depending on the signal input, but generally a line-level audio signal isn't going to get anywhere near the limits of a common op-amp on those.

Should go without saying but that circuit wants a split-rail power supply. ±5 to ±18 is usually what you're aiming for, but some op-amps (especially JFET-input op-amps) want a wider range rather than a smaller range. Best to use an iron transformer-based power supply with linear regulators and sufficiently large caps. If you absolutely have to use a switching power supply (can be very noisy with audio circuits) then ensure you tie the ground rail to protective earth, and try to use LC filters or capacitive multipliers or zener-pass regulators on the power rails to block that noise. Common linear regulators are bad at blocking high-frequency ripple.

>>2520866
so here is the explanation:
first of all voltmeters are essentially ammeters with a resistance in series with them.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voltmeter
understanding that will allow us to understand the circuit behavior.
starting with circuit A like in my pic:
current flows from the voltage source into the resistor and voltmeter to the cap and back to the source.
the current flow is in the same direction in the voltmeter and the resister hence the positive voltage.
as the capacitor charges the voltage across it increases, and thus the current across the resistor and voltmeter decrease until it stops completely when the cap fully charges, the potential difference across the resistor and voltmeter is zero at steady state.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2520900
>>2520897
>>2520866
for circuit B a similar things happen but with a tiny trick, the voltmeter is a significant current path...
assuming the current flows from the the source to the resistor this creates a potential across the cap as current flows, simultaneously current is flowing in the voltmeter however it is in the opposite direction to the resistor hence the negative voltage.
as the voltage across the cap equals zero, the current across the voltmeter will equal zero, and thus the voltage across the voltmeter will be zero at steady state.

mentally this makes sense, but considering ur component values u wouldn't have been able to measure it with a cheap of the shelf multimeter, since for circuit A it would take 0.1 ms and for circuit B 0.1s to reach zero...
idk it just seems unlikely that u have actually have seen these observations since most of the shelf meters' refresh rate is 180Hz at best, and screen refresh rates rarely exceed 2-4Hz...
just seems a bit fishy yk....

name: Anonymous
com:
Power, Water, Heating, Cooling, Septic.
What's the best way to handle the big five off-grid?

>Power
Hydro is king, but flowing water is uncommon. Solar is weak and requires several parts that eventually need replacement. When power is abundant you get secondary systems for heating/cooling/etc. This one is hard.

>Water
Rainwater catchment? A water tower or attic water tank for gravity fed water? Maybe an underground cistern so it won't freeze, but then you lack gravity assistance.

>Heating
Can't beat wood. A secondary system should be in place, but a wood stove provides efficient heat and a cooking surface. Easy.

>Cooling
Hardest on the list. There is no simple wood stove-esque equivalent for cooling. Geothermal has promise but it's underpowered and expensive to install.

>Septic
Dead easy. You can put in your own tanks and outhouses just fine.

Bought the creality 0.5W laser. The power is definitely lacking, but even then if it had decent focus it would still be usable for what I want (burning away thin etch-resistant coatings). Watch out though, the third party software availability for turning a 3D printer into a laser is kinda shit. Lightburn is almost certainly the way to go, but it's not FOSS. Already using the system on our current house. installed it all ourselves. we generate about 40% of our power. running since March.

we have 2 load panels (breaker boxes) in our house. one is original, one installed by us. the one we installed is SOLAR ONLY. the two DO NOT CROSS in any way. our solar load panel is 100% off-grid. no grid-tie.

this powers 40% of our house. the rest is on grid.

when we move into the new house we are building, we will expand solar system. our aim is to be self sufficient in two to three years. house should be complete in 3-4 months.

current array is 2440 W. we have 8 FLA batteries wired 4s2p. running on a Sol-Ark 12k charge controller inverter.

upgrade will include switching to LiFePo4 batteries. 3x Fortress Eflex. we will add more as cash flow allows. we live debt-free, so no financing.

sub: What went wrong with my soap?
com:
This batch had 9.5% pine tar in it by weight and was soaped at 130 degrees to encourage gel phase. The soap, despite being liquid as the tar was being added, instantly seized and turned lumpy after the tar and hydroxide were added even with minimal stirring.

I mixed the soap to as homogenous of a mixture as I could get before adding cedar wood extract and charcoal powder which caused it to separate and seize again. Despite this I still tried to make the soap become homogenous again and then molded it.

After setting in the mold for 2 days the soap came out reeking of old car tires and disappointment. It was also leaking a substantial amount of rancid oil which came out in rivers as I cut the soap. Most disappointingly the soap was filled with balls of acrid smelling tar which had failed to mix despite it looking homogenous when molded.

Did I simply use too much tar? Should I have melted the tar and fats together instead of adding it with the hydroxide?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: maybe next time skip the rancid oil and acrid smelling tar idk that's just me but i'd try it without those ingredients couldn't hurt you know?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: why tar?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2520204
-Mix the pine tar in with the rest of the melted oils before adding the lye mixture.

-Use a lower temp like 70-80F instead of 130F. Pine tar soaps cook off really fast and with minimal stirring compared to other soaps. This probably didn't work in your favor either.

-Make sure that you're considering the pine tar as an oil when you calculate your lye amount.

Airlocks aren't that complicated, you just need two doors.

>open inner door

But, the intake to the tank is like a damn firehose, it comes from way up the hills. I tee off that for the garden hose already. Basically I plan to tee off that intake pipe again and bypass around the tank, with picrel to control pressure and just ease it up a little, and still have water store in the tank too.

I'm thinking things like the shitty old toilet valve starting to leak or some sound of water hammer at the taps? well you can get a regulator for like 50 bucks. just make sure it can handle your input pressure and that it also can allow enough flow at your desired output pressure. They typically have a chart in the box. Which means you have to be sneaky and open the box in the store.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2520673
Problem with running a tube up is that it only gives you high pressure if you're not drawing any water out of it. As soon as you open the valve the tube will empty out and the pressure will rapidly drop until you've just got a tank's worth of pressure again. The way to get continuous high pressure out of the system would be to move the entire tank to the top of the hill.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

The friction of the line itself will reduce the head pressure. You may not need to do anything.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2520752
Friction losses only happen when there's water flowing through the system. If the flow stops downstream of the tank then your system becomes deadlocked and you reach hydrostatic pressure.

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The back and sides are melamine. It's a pretty shit product to pocket hole or attempt to screw with any kind of security. It's fine for nailer boards like mounting uppers with pan head screws. But there it's simply sandwiched between the screw and the wall.
If you attempt to pull things together by going into the melamine with a screw, it will tear out almost immediately. MDF even is much stronger.

I would glue up with silicone. This will hold until you decide to peel things apart again then can be scraped off. Most cabinets have a corner clip of plastic or wood and you simply screw up into the countertop. A bead of silicone across the top surface would be plenty here. It doesn't need to be a fancy caulk job.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
What you are holding there is the cladding from an uranium fuel rod, most likely a souvenir from a decommissioned nuclear reactor. They are usually encased in a shielded container and only taken out for educational purposes, with appropriate protection, as they can still be quite "hot" for decades after removal.

Uranium is twice as dense a lead, that's why it is so incredibly heavy.

For proof, here's me holding one that has been decontaminated and is well intact.

Yours appears to be slightly darker in color and shows a significant amount of wear, which indicates that the chromium coating (the shiny finish) has started to erode over time.

This is not good, and you really do not want to hold that with your bare hands.


Are there any markings on it??

The most important pump to be backed up is the sump, and the septic.
I tried using a 1200 watt UPS on the sump pump, it does not work. Breaks the fuse every time.
I looked at buying HD battery charger, and backup, but thats $1500 in parts and will only work on one side of the basement unless i run a bunch of extension cords, which I dont want to do.
What are my options?
Whole house battery thing like one of those Tesla things? or similar? are there kits for this?

By the time you've done the above, you might as well wire in a couple solar panels and attach the whole thing to your breaker panel, because you've pretty much built the expensive part of a whole home solar system.

com:

>went in to the office to inform the designer expecting to get a proper bollocking

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518885
It was the combination of a few factors, but the biggest one is called "dot gain". Colors are made by mixing size and location of dots in 4 different colors. Sort of like how digital screens mix RGB pixels together to create colors.

When you print those dots, there are factors that can make the dots larger or smaller than intended. In this case the paper it was printed on absorbed the ink more, creating larger dots. There might have been other factors, I don't know.

The ad was already very dark and moody looking to begin with. I did one quick pre-press at a local printer, and it came out dark... I had them lighten it a bit and due to time/money had to send the files right away.

I was really proud of the ad. It was my first "big" print ad, and I also handled the photography and design from top to bottom. Like, I was planning on framing a copy of it lol.

sub: Retrofitting a light tower trailer generator
com: I've been thinking of modifying a light tower trailer ever since I came across a Kubota D1105T a few months back. The idea was to retrofit a trailer with the aforementioned engine and power my house and potentially remote cabin. Recently I bought a light tower trailer with a Kubota D905 and 6kW gen head and have been cleaning it up. The idea is to ditch the 6kW head and upgrade, while installing the Kubota D1105T in place. Had a few questions for anyone who knows these engines pretty well, or had this type of idea. Both of the engines above come from different applications. The Kubota D905 engine has a mfg sticker mentioning 'constant speed only'. I've disassembled the engine far enough to compare the governor assemblies and I'm stuck scratching my head. Both engines seem to have the exact same assemblies from what I can tell. Seemingly the only factors keeping the smaller engine at a "constant speed" are the throttle control screws on the outside of the engine. If my plan is to put the D1105T (variable speed) in the trailer, and maybe down the line throw the D905 (constant speed) in a utv build, am I going to have to change any internal governor components in either engine?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Load will determine the final rpm. You can lock any throttle position on both of those engines or vary them.

Cooling can be an issue in overloaded diesel engines so additional airflow over the radiator may be necessary.

name: Anonymous
com: I found out my local butcher sells sheep heads. How do I go about cleaning one? Guides online say all I have to do is boil, scour, and soak in bleach. Are there other ways that don't require the special beetles? I'm afraid steps one and three of the Alaskan gov's guide, boiling and bleaching, will weaken the bone. Step two will leave marks, no? Has anyone gone about this before and has tips? I want to adorn my wall with a sheep's skull like Neolithic villagers in the Zagros. pic unrelated

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
If you live in the city, you're going to have problems.

The best way would be to use a combination of what people above have mentioned. Find somewhere where you can leave it for a few weeks and let nature take its course. Obviously it needs to be secured to stop larger predators taking it. After most of the flesh etc. is gone, you want to soak it in a bucket of water for a while to get into all the nooks and crannies. Adding a small amount of dish soap will help things along. Take it out and give it a good scrub and change the water every week or so. At this stage the teeth may potentially come loose so make sure you don't loose any. The dish soap is essential for degreasing the bones. To get a nice white finish, soak them in a 1:3 mixture of hydrogen peroxide to water.

Under no circumstances boil them as this will only trap the fat inside the bone and make them rot and smell. It also undermines the structural integrity of the bone. Also never use bleach as this will also weaken the bone structure.

Finally join a Facebook group for bone collectors or taxidermists. There are lot's of great communities that are happy help and will teach you a thing or two.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2519642
I advise against leaving skulls out in nature that long. First, despite your best security, a larger animal may figure out a way to move it. Second, weathering patterns are not going to be uniform. A long, long time ago when I was first collecting animal skulls, I left a red fox skeleton in a cage in the woods for over a year. The part of the skull facing up got sun bleached with an awful pitted texture. The part facing down got stained green from mold. You really only want it to be outside for as long as it takes for insects to clean most of the flesh, then you want to move it to the water buckets. Ideally, we can all have space for indoor beetle tanks, but we don't. You've gotta check on them every few weeks.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518598
With PLA I've had the best luck turning the mold upside down and melting at 400C. Then turn up to 450C which will cause anything left to burn out. The kitchen oven won't quiet do it, so I made my own out of a stovetop heating element, inswool, PID, and a washing machine drum. I found a 3D printing filament "Mold-Lay" that is low temp enough to be melted out in the kitchen oven, but still makes a smoky mess and more expensive than PLA. I usually use 50% sand 50% plaster. The 45 minute plaster works better than the 15 minute plaster (and is cheaper too). Use a paint brush to paint the mixture on the surface before fully submerging to make sure it fills all the nooks and crannies. Using 356 aluminum rather than potluck aluminum will give much better results (found someone on Ebay selling for $3/lb).

/diy/ I need some advice please so that I don't get fucked around by conmen
I have to get 4 windows (all are around 1m W x 1.5m H) and 1 patio door (1.8m W x 2m H)
My main reason to get the work done (and I do want it done somewhat urgently) is to reduce the amount of heat escaping because most of these windows are old/leaking heat out

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
You don't necessarily need composite if you get pvc with foam insulation in the frame channels. Things like low e glazing help (some people think they're a scam, I haven't made up my mind yet). Argon gas is also pretty standard these days but that dissipates.

Dual pane glass should be fine. Biggest thing is making sure it's installed right and knowing that if you do go with a purely vinyl window there will be sag down the line with operable windows.
As for the patio door a slider will always be less efficienct than French doors, but French doors are typically more expensive. If you go with French doors pay the extra for fiberglass as they are typically better insulated than steel, and steel dent/rusts/demlainates much easier.

You won't get anything quickly unless your shit is all whatever is standard sizes in bongland, and that's only for the door. There are no "standard" window sizes but you might get lucky and have your RO be close to sizes that manufacturers run in bulk.

Quickest fix is plastic wrap and blankets over the windows.

My girlfriend loses her glasses about three times a year. I find them all over the house and in the car. I found them in the trunk once. Also in the top rack of the dishwasher once. Meanwhile I have never lost a pair and I have been wearing them since I was a kid. I have places I put them down; my nightstand, my desk, and the counter in the bathroom for when I am showers. I don't put them anywhere that is not those places. Do the same thing with your tools.

Have designated work areas and storage areas. Similar things should be in the same place. Don't have half your sockets in one toolbox and half in the other, etc. When you are done with a job (or it is on hold) you clean up the area and put shit back where it goes *even if you still need the tools for that job*. When work stops the tools get put away every time. Everything should have its place. That place should be the first place you look for a thing. If you find yourself looking somewhere else first, *move the thing to that place*.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2519288
Honest answer - if you're not living in it, as long as you have time/money, you could get it done. But it's realistically a tear-down. You're basically rebuilding the house at this point, I guarantee that it needs all new plumbing, wiring, septic, etc. So you're replacing everything. How much is too much, for your budget? When/if do you plan to live in it? What's the neighborhood like, for potential rental income?
I mean, with some study and going slowly, you might get some of it done. You want professionals dealing with the roof, and electrical/plumbing.
This has every red flag for being a complete money pit. To what end? What is your final plan for the house? What is your realistic potential here?
If you plan to live in it, that's one thing. But if you want to fix it up to flip it, you could put a bunch of money into it, but won't be able to sell it for what it's now worth, if prices are lower in that area.
Your time, your money. Could be a big toilet you flush a big chunk of your paycheck into every month, for little or no return.

Like another anon said, get an inspector in there. Go over every inch of the house. Then get estimates from electricians, plumbers, and hvac for what they consider to be legal/recommended upgrades, while you get the shell of the house repaired. Maybe call around local contractors and see if they'd be willing to consult and just sit down and write you out a general plan, and throw them some of the work, like the roof.
Get the foundation checked first, like other anons have said. If that's fucked, you're fucked.

>It's very efficient coupled with a heat pump, cause you need lower temps, with gas or other types of furnace there's no difference.
i want to add to this that that you're able to transfer the same amount of heat at a lower temperature than with a regular radiator because the surface area is a lot higher.
and we all know heat pumps are more effficient with lower temperature differences
there's a small increase in efficiency with furnaces as well because there's less losses through the pipes and the temperature distribution is far more evenly across the room. with a radiator (usually places near windows) you create hot spots that increase losses to the outside

>you're polite enough
Yeah, I was gonna be snarky but this is true.
How much air conditioner to buy is the other question. The simple answer is: as much as you can afford. Bigger units are more efficient in general. And you'll run them less often to maintain temperature. (There is such a thing as too much, but it's rare and weird.)
As a VERY rough rule-of-thumb, you want about 30BTU per sq ft. E.g. a 16ftx16ft room is an 9000BTU AC. Or one notch bigger. Or one notch smaller.
>If you have a sliding DOOR, or a fucked-up push out window (I have one), consider getting a unit on rolling casters.
If you do go this route, be sure to get one which has two flexible tubes that go to the door/window. Why? Because the one tube model just exhausts the hot air out, which lowers the air pressure in the room, so every little window leak and vent and whatever you have outside is going to be pouring hot outside air into the room you're trying to cool. Two-tube systems circulate the outside air across the condensing coil and keep pressure normal.

com:
Has anyone installed crown molding before?

I work as a handyman and do mostly paint and drywall. Today a customer asked me to put up some crown molding. I said sure. After 2 hours and like 5 missed cuts, I just gave up and told the customer I could not do it.

Anyone worked with this shit? How do you get this thing down?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518630
I do cabinets. Most of these get crown and light rail. I came up through several other carpentry positions to get into the higher detail work. I was on crews that wouldn't let me touch a stick of crown, but they were happy to send me up a ladder with sandpaper to fix their cuts.

I always think of this song
https://youtu.be/ujmGiBl36f8
Crown is cut Upside Down and Backwards. It is important that you rest the crown correctly against your miter fence. You'll notice that it rocks against the fence and base, so I generally make the start of the cut or installed physical bottom of the crown piece flat against the fence because your angle will change if it's not.

Cabs are good to start because they're clean boxes to wrap. If you're touching ceilings and walls, especially on an old house, you know what you're getting into. They're going to be up and down across the span. They're not going to be right angles. It will often be worth your time to cope the crown like the OP image because coping gives you more angle of acceptable installation. On really ugly ceilings, you might end up scribing the top edge of the crown then adjusting the height by bringing spots down with a belt sander or free handing on the table saw.

Most of the answer is in building a good mitre box and using s lot of clamps to hold the piece in there.
The one depicted in >>2518644 is traditional. But for moulding you also want a 45° that rises parallel to the flat this will put a 45° bevel on both pieces so that the patter meets itself between them. So special sawing. name: Anonymous
com:
How would I go about making my own cases, keycaps, buttons, and switches with printed lettering, logos, etc. for my electronics projects (a handheld computer, for example)? I want to have a similar level of quality to at least 1980s consumer products, not perfect but at least good looking and robust.

A 3D printer would be an obvious starting point, but some of the particulars like the brushed aluminum surfacing or a folded sheet metal case would require different tools and processes. What are some tools I'd need, and what processes would be required to achieve this kind of build quality?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
For more "quality" fit-and-finish like brushed aluminum surfaces or that calculator you posted; the calculator's case is stamped aluminum, a process too costly in tooling to make economical for small projects. It is also why nearly everything is injection molded plastic cases today. You can look at laser or water jet cutting thin plates of brushed aluminum as a type of manufacturing for a panel or enclosure face.

If you want to really get into crazy DIY rabbit hole expertise, check out Ben Krasnow's "Applied Science" channel on youtube.

Good luck anon, I hope the best success for your projects, post results sometime.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518654
>>2518656
>>2518658
I'm in Australia, so sourcing stuff like keycaps and silicone might be a bit trickier, but I'll see what I can find.

For the metal fabrication I could probably work with what I've got in my shed, but the main question I need an answer to is how manufacturers put text and logos on their products? Is there a specific process that can be done at home to achieve the same results?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518734
Silicone can be hard to get text and logos to stay on if done in fine detail by hand. You would have to find a silicon bonding paint or dye and then paint the reverse image in the mold and then pour over it, which might give some results you could try to refine.

You may be better off looking into labelling the faceplate of the button/switch/key/housing. In that case you can look at water transfer decals with a finishing coat (polyurethane?) to protect from rubbing off, silkscreening (lots of color choices), or laser engraving and then wiping in a color inlay in the etching (good for single color). Each different method has increased costs in tooling. "Applied Science" has a silkscreening video, and also you can see what "DIY silkscreen electronics" search yields.

Silkscreen is sometimes taught at community or continuing education centers, or whatever the equivalent might be called in Australia. Laser engravers are not too expensive depending on what you want. I've never done water decals on a finished product other than model airplanes/cars etc. but they are legitimately used in small batch productions.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518734
Also, if you are having trouble sourcing silicone mix materials, try looking in your country's film industry sector; many of the silicone suppliers sell to that business because silicone, moldable foams, urethanes, polymer clay, etc. is used extensively in the film industry for prop making and character creation. Just a largely overlooked but super-specific niche DIY market to make fake items that look real for film.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518599
Made some cases:
If plastics are okay, then vacuum form from acrylic or other sheet. It’s a really easy process and diy suitable, you just need a die that’s cnc cut or 3D printed.

For metal cases if you have an adequate press rubber pressing and stamping/punching is doable. You do need punches/dies. Standard shaped punches can be bought, but the dies for rubber pressing and stamping need to be CNC’d or otherwise manufactured from steel. For simple rectangular case an angle grinder could work though
